newsitem.title: USA: Western U.S. spot power rises on end of fish flush.
newsitem.headline: Western U.S. spot power rises on end of fish flush.

text.p: West Coast spot power prices rose slightly Tuesday following the expiration of fish-related requirements at the end of August for extra water through the hydroelectric power dams in the U.S. Northwest.
The additional flows are aimed at aiding the seasonal migration of endangered species.
"We are out of the period of having to push a certain amount of water down rivers," said a Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) trader.
"Now we can control how much surplus we generate."

BPA raised today its price for next-day peak sales by $2.00 to $20.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) for 1100-2200 PDT delivery. The federal power marketing agency's off-peak offer for Wednesday delivery was unchanged at $13.00.
Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) prices were bid early Tuesday at $19.50 during peak hours Wednesday, compared with $15.00 on Friday. Next-day, off-peak Mid-C electricity was discussed at $13.00.
Next-day California-Oregon border (COB) electricity was offered in the high $18.00s, with confirmed trades at $18.00. Off-peak COB prices were unchanged near $12.50.
October COB prices were assessed at $15.75-$16.50, a wider and slightly firmer range than the $15.85-$16.00 seen Friday.
"Air-conditioning loads are down," noted another Northwest utility trader. "Today's market has more to do with water than with weather."
The National Weather Service forecast below-normal temperatures through most of the Northwest and Northern California next week.
But some market sources noted the start of the school year could help mitigate some of the expected load drop-off.
Still, power demand in the Southwest is seen trending downward amid the onset of autumn.
"Our peak is over. And temperatures in the Northwest are expected to be 5 to 10 degrees below normal for the next few days," said a utility trader in New Mexico.
At the Palo Verde (PV) switchyard in Arizona, next-day firm delivery electricity was quoted $24.00-25.00 for peak hours, up slightly from $24.00 on Friday. October PV was quoted at $16.45-!6.75.
-- D Beasley, Los Angeles News Bureau +1 213-380-2014
